metadata.title: 5 Ways To Become A Better Machine Learning Practitioner | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 5 Ways To Become A Better Machine Learning Practitioner
metadata.description: What does it take to become a better Data Scientist, Machine Learning Engineer, ML Researcher or *insert machine learning practitioner role here*? Within this article, you’ll find five methods of…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: podcast of an interview between myself and Ken Jee(Data Science YouTuber)

all_paragraphs: What does it take to become a better Data Scientist, Machine Learning Engineer, ML Researcher or *insert machine learning practitioner role here*?
A lot of reading, writing, learning, failing, coding, training…you get the point.
Essentially, it requires experience, determination and persistence.
Within this article, you’ll find five methods of becoming a better ML Practioner I've picked up from both my ML related studies or experiences in my ML profession.
I have to be honest here; I won’t make you the best ML practitioner by the time you have read this article.

But I’ll provide you with a bunch of tools, resources, advice and anecdotes that encapsulate general approaches to becoming, a better ML practitioner, that you can implement within your routine immediately.
If you feel there might be apparent approaches that I’ve left out of this article, I invite you to share within the comments section whatever approach has worked for you.
Most, if not all, professions and disciplines within the Artificial intelligence field demand constant learning.
This is mainly because AI as a field could be said to still be in its infancy.
Using GPU for training machine learning models was only introduced less than a decade ago.

The AI field is evolving and progressing every day, and this means Data Scientists, ML Engineers, ML Researchers and all forms of ML practitioners are required to continually keep up to date with new techniques, applications, algorithms and more.
I can’t imagine a time in my career where I will have to stop reading research papers, medium articles or blog posts that are AI-related.

When you become an ML practitioner, regardless of whatever level, you are expected not to get complacent with the current knowledge you have, because, in a few months or years, there’s always a new state of the art technology that beats all previously set benchmarks.

I recall back in my MSc in Machine Learning and Computer Vision studies; Deep learning was mainly about convolutional networks, object detection, instance segmentation and the different variants of widely used CNN architectures, this was just in 2018.
Now I could bet the curriculum is updated to include topics around large scale language models, Transformer architecture, real-time computer vision and more.
How can machine learning practitioners keep learning constantly?
The rest of the advice within the article, if implemented, will ensure that you are within an environment where quality and machine learning relevant information is abundant.
Teaching is the best form of learning; someone once said, not sure who.
Ever since I took my very first online course on Machine Learning taught by none other than Andrew Ng, I’ve been very eager to inform my colleagues and people around what I’ve learnt.
Relaying all information I got from my learnings back to curious individuals who wanted to know more about ML and AI techniques, improved my understanding and explainability of several ML topics.

Fast forward to a couple of years later, and I’m still communicating information on what I’m currently studying. This time I’m not only telling people face to face, but I’m also reaching out to several hundred, and sometimes thousands of people, through sharing my knowledge through articles.
The more you challenge yourself to be able to understand a topic to the point where you can educate another person on that topic, the more of a better ML practitioner you become.

Data Scientists and ML practitioners collaborate with several team members that have no idea of what terms and terminologies like, principal component analysis, gradient descent or hyperparameter tuning means.
It’s our job as ML practitioners to be able to explain ML ideas, techniques and concepts in layman terms, especially to a non-technical audience.
Try writing a couple of Medium articles explaining how object detection techniques work, or why not explain how convolutional neural layers functions within the broader CNN architecture.
This section is closely related to the points made in section 1.
I’m not talking about reading news articles on the banning of facial recognition software or reading casual tech blogs.
To keep up to date with the ‘real’ developments and progress occurring within the AI field, you have to seek more technical, relevant and direct sources.
What do I mean by this?

Don’t get me wrong news articles and casual tech blogs share information that’s useful. Still, you have to realise that most of the information within these platforms are intended for the broader audience.
To become a better machine learning practitioner, you have to get your news developments straight from the horse’s mouth.
List of blogs you need to be aware of as an ML practitioner:
I have to admit that some content within the blogs above can be very technical and hard to understand. But as an ML practitioner working on getting better, you shouldn’t shy away from a challenge.
Whenever I come across challenging concepts, techniques or ideas presented within direct AI blogs, I break them down into smaller components and research these components.
Eventually, the knowledge and information obtained from researching the smaller component all sum up to an understanding of the initial broader concept or idea.
Podcasts from AI and tech-based sources are an excellent way to stay in touch with AI developments without using as much mental power or focus as reading research papers or technical blogs.
Most forms of AI/ML/DS based podcasts I listen to are typically in an interview-style form.

Interviews have a personal element that I particularly appreciate, sometimes listening to AI pioneers or ML practitioner talk about their journey and share information feels very human, as opposed to reading it off a tech blog or an article.
The personal touch of a podcast is one that I feel you can comprehend right this moment.

No seriously, within this article, I’ve touched on some of my experiences and knowledge within the AI field, but watch this podcast of an interview between myself and Ken Jee(Data Science YouTuber), and you might understand the personal element I’m referring to.
Pre-covid era, I listened to a lot more podcasts on my daily commute to and from work.
Now I have a more distilled list of podcasts I listen to daily, mainly because I spend more time on Medium and other tech blogs, and don’t have to commute to work anymore.
Below is a list of podcasts I’m currently tuned into:
By now, you probably realise that I’ve created somewhat of an ecosystem of information sources that keep me informed of developments associated with AI.
The last piece of this ecosystem is newsletters.
I check my email at least once every hour, and I find it enriching when I see a newsletter from one of the AI information sources I subscribe to.
I see these emails as breaks from the other mundane and long emails in my inbox.

Newsletters are similar to tech blog or articles, but shorter, in the sense that they usually contain a summary of essential information. The contents within newsletters are supplemented with a link to a corresponding external article that goes into more in-depth knowledge.
Here are a few newsletters I’m subscribed to:
All the other four advice and tips on how to become a better ML practitioner help towards expanding your horizon and knowledge of the AI field.

But I feel that it’s crucial to isolate the importance of expanding your horizon and knowledge and write a few paragraphs on this. More specifically, I’ll touch on distinct use cases that apply to ML practitioners.
A caveat of operating within a profession that involves working with programming languages and software is that there is never a shortage of libraries and frameworks.
Should I learn TensorFlow or PyTorch?
Should I use Docker or Anaconda?
These are questions that I asked myself during my early days within the machine learning field.
For a long career in machine learning, it’s useful to learn all, or at least have some experience using as many tools and languages as possible.

It makes sense to have a technology stack that you have expertise in and feel confident using. But there are benefits to be realised from exploring adjacent tools, similar to tools within primary tech stack.

You can expand your horizon vertically, where you can get expertise within a tool/language/software, or horizontally, where you explore adjacent and similar tools and languages to your proprietary tech stack.

One notable benefit of expanding your horizon and knowledge when it comes to tools, libraries and software packages is that there’s always a potential to add more technology and expertise to your existing skillset, which makes you in turn highly employable and marketable.
You are literally increasing your value within the machine learning job market with each language, library and tool you gain experience in.
Lately, I’ve gained interests in psychology and understanding the human mind.
My interest in this topic is not at the point where I need to go back to an academic institution to get the relevant knowledge.
Still, I have purchased a couple of books on personality, the human mind and human behaviour.
Exploring a different domain that, in some manner, relates to the whole discussion around AI provides me with versatility in my thinking and perspective when approaching machine learning problems.
This is probably one of the most effective methods of ensuring you are the best ML practitioner you can be.
Personal projects can be seen as one's curiosity to either explore solutions to problems or create an understanding of the world around them.

Solution exploration and creation of understanding are examples of the advantages of technology; they are typically the primary output we as humans expect from technology application or other incarnations.
Most ML practitioners start their learning journey through a series of video courses or ML/DS textbooks.
There comes a time when anyone embarking on their ML learning journey will have to transition from online video courses or books to actual hands-on projects.
For many, personal projects fill the void of experience and expertise between studies and a machine learning role.
For some, a personal project is the beginning of a new tech startup, venture or business.
For you, a personal project is an opportunity to showcase to the world your technical ability and creativeness.
It’s a door that leads to endless possibilities.
Becoming a better Machine Learning Practioner is not just about getting a job promotion or having ‘Senior’ next to your job title.
A good ML practitioner continuously improves their skill set, mindset, business acumen, collaboration skills and more.
A good ML practitioner is always chasing knowledge and expertise.
A good ML practitioner takes every opportunity to learn and teach.
A good ML practitioner…you get the point.
It’s understandable that the path to becoming an ML practitioner that provides unreplaceable value is hard.
In my current journey of trying to become the best Computer Vision Engineer I can be, I’ve faced obstacles and doubts; some call it imposter syndrome.
But then I remember that as long as I’m better than I was yesterday, then I’m at least doing something right.
The tips and advice in this article are helpful, but I’m sure seasoned ML practitioners reading this article have one or two tips they can add to this list.
Feel free to share any other methods of becoming a better ML practitioner that you are aware of in the comment section.
To connect with me or find more content similar to this article, do the following:

Machine Learning Content Creator with 1M+ views— Computer Vision Engineer. Interested in gaining and sharing knowledge on Technology and Finance
